results.title: Jump the fence
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Lucy MacLaren and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Two young girls who feel restricted at home decide to escape in a gelati van. After a short burst of freedom they end up in Winlaton, a girls’ training centre.

results.title: Bingo, bridesmaids and braces
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Tristram Miall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In this documentary the lives of three working class women are examined as they grow up from the “not so innocent” age of fourteen, to “it’s happening too fast” at eighteen, through to “well we survived”, at the ripe young age of 26. During these years we witness the women confronting the very real issues of teenage pregnancy, love versus sex, and career choices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Tristram Miall and Film Australia

results.title: Radio day
results.brief_description: A promotional exercise that shows a day in the life of radio station 3XY in Melbourne. Although most of the activities carried out in a commercial radio station are depicted, there is no attempt to explain why and as such this production does little to demystify the process. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Attack of the strange insects from Uranus
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This mockumentary, depicting the zombie apocalypse, contains a hilarious collection of violence and gore. (Note that some scenes may disturb some viewers).

results.title: For love or money: a history of women and work in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Megan McMurchy, Margot Nash, Margot Oliver and Flashback Films
results.brief_description: Tells the story of women’s working lives throughout Australia’s history. Juxtaposes clips from feature films, home movies, newsreels and documentaries with radio shows, diaries, popular songs, letters and interviews. Explores the challenges that face women in the nuclear age. Narrated by Noni Hazlehurst; edited by Margot Nash; music by Elizabeth Drake.
results.title_for_label: For love or money: a history of women and work in Australia
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeni Thornley, Megan McMurchy, Margot Nash, Margot Oliver and Flashback Films

results.title: Maidens
results.brief_description: A compilation documentary of four generations of the filmmaker’s maternal family from 1906-1977 using images from old family photographs, slides, home movies and excerpts from historical Australian women’s films. The images trace the transition of the family from the extended family functioning as a productive unit on the land to the nuclear family and by the fourth generation into further disintegration and change into a yet to be defined form. Parts 1 & 11 illustrate the historical development of the image and its use by families in reading personal history. Parts 3 & 4 juxtapose fictional dramatic films in which the filmmaker appears with cinema verite and home movies thus exploring the relationship between filmic representation and reality. First Prize, General Section, Greater Union Awards, Sydney Film Festival 1978. Gold Hugo, Best Short Subject Film, Chicago Film Festival 1978.

results.title: Given a chance
results.creator_credit: Clayton Jacobson and Barwon Youth Employment Office for the Employment Access Program, Community Services Victoria
results.brief_description: A program targeting employers, CES, welfare and youth workers assisting disadvantaged youth in the labour market. A positive image of such job seekers is promoted through interviews with young people and employers regarding their success. Provides background information about Victorian Juvenile Justice and Protective Services in relation to employing young people. Explains the role of the Employment Access Program.

results.title: Rocking the foundations
results.creator_credit: Pat Fiske, Australian Film Commission. Creative Development Branch and Bower Bird Films
results.brief_description: A film that goes behind the headlines to look at the extraordinary chain of events that has made the New South Wales Builders’ Labourers’ Federation the controversial part of Australian history that it is today. It is a story about workers who began to act for themselves and make decisions about issues that affected ordinary people. Also looks at the new policies that saw women introduced into the building industry, limited tenure of office and the use of union power to assist resident action and environmental groups. Narrated by Pat Fiske. (NOTE: 16mm print is black and white.)

results.title: head_phone_film_poems
results.material_description: Multi channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
head_phone_film_poems is a collection of thirteen films that creatively remix material from online archives including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) film material in the National Archives of Australia, crime scene photographs from the Justice and Police Museum Sydney, and Gibson’s own social-media-stored collection of strange late-night phenomena filmed in his neighbourhood over the past decade. Drawing on these caches of ‘readymade’ footage, the head_phone_film_poems are shaped by three guiding principles: they must be produced entirely on the iPhone, they must feature some visualised language and they must suggest an enormous amount more than they show.

[Sourced from ACMI website event page https://www.acmi.net.au/whats-on/ross-gibson-head_phone_film_poems/ 9/6/2021]
